Spacecraft Module

The spacecraft module defines the spacecraft object, which can be used to simulate spacecraft observations of the Earth. Each spacecraft object relies on the SPICE framework, specifically the SpiceyPy Python API, to determine its state and attitude with time. Examples of spacecraft object use can be found in the scripts/ directory, and the general functionality is described below. If the user is not familiar with SPICE, we encourage them to visit the NAIF webpage and read the introductory documentation.

Before using this module, the user should ensure that the necessary SPICE kernels have been downloaded into FOAM’s cache directory (~/.foam). This can be done by calling get_spice_kernels() from the foam.utils.config module (if the user hasn’t already run get_all_ancillary_data() from that module).

Setting Up a Spacecraft Object

Upon initialization, the spacecraft object loads background SPICE kernels (e.g. Earth’s reference frame, leapsecond lists, etc.) into the kernel pool. The user must then write the kernels relevant to the spacecraft object through the spacecraft.write_tle_kernels() method. These kernels are formed from Two Line Element (TLE) sets. Users can provide pre-existing TLE text files to the write_tle_kernels() method or generate their own using the spacecraft.get_manual_elems() method. In addition to establishing spacecraft position and velocity with respect to Earth as a function of time, a spacecraft coordinate system is also generated. For this coordinate system, the unit vector \(\hat{x}\) points towards the sub-spacecraft point on Earth, the unit vector \(\hat{y}\) points in the direction of the spacecraft orbital velocity, and the \(\hat{z}\) axis is orthogonal to \(\hat{x}\) and \(\hat{y}\) following the right hand rule. This system is illustrated in the figure below.

After the spacecraft SPICE kernels are written, the user can then specify pointing directions for any number of radiometers using the spacecraft.write_radiometer_ck() method. Stationary and scanning radiometers can be specified using the arguments to this function, and any number of radiometers can be specified for a single spacecraft. For convenience, methods are provided to generate spacecraft objects similar to the SMAP and Aquarius missions as make_smap() and make_aquarius().

Interacting with a Spacecraft Object

Following the creation of a spacecraft object, the main mode of interaction with the objects are the spacecraft.make_track_grid() and spacecraft.make_obs_grid() methods. Both of these methods return dictionaries of position and attitude data over a user-specified period of time. The make_track_grid() method returns the sub-spacecraft latitude and longitude for each spacecraft. The make_obs_grid() (and the experimental make_parallel_grid()) method returns pointing information for each radiometer on the spacecraft, specifically the latitude/longitude of the intersection of the radiometer boresight with the surface of the Earth, the topocentric incidence elevation and azimuth angles, and the right ascension and declination in the direction of specular reflection. Also include are flags indicating whether or not the sun or moon is in the path of this specularly reflected vector. The output dictionaries from these methods can then be used to generate brightness temperature maps. These methods are also used by revisit_time() to make maps of spacecraft revisit for a given period. An example workflow for generating a spacecraft object, observing dictionary, and revisit time chart are shown below.

 1from foam.spacecraft import spacecraft, strings_to_epochs, revisit_time
 2from foam.utils.mk import manual_furnish
 3
 4eps = strings_to_epochs('2020 MAY 01 12:00 UTC', '2020 JUL 01 12:00 UTC')
 5epoch_res = 10  # seconds
 6
 7# Equivalent to foam.spacecraft.make_smap
 8manual_furnish()  # Loads SPICE kernels
 9smap_craft = spacecraft()
10# SMAP TLE
11tle = ['1 40376U 15003A   20247.33652497  .00000025  00000-0  13841-4 0  9991',
12       '2 40376  98.1240 252.7233 0001762  90.8135 269.3273 14.63327320298611']
13epoch, elements = spice.getelm(2000, 500, tle)
14smap_craft.write_tle_kernels(elems=elements, tle_epoch=epoch, start_epoch=start_epoch,
15                             end_epoch=end_epoch, epoch_res=epoch_res)
16# look_angle, look_axis, rpm, scan_axis
17smap_craft.write_radiometer_ck(35.5, 'Y', 14.6, 'X')
18
19# End make_smap utility
20
21track_res = 50e-3  # seconds
22grid, lon_bins, lat_bins, obs_dict = revisit_time(smap_craft, *eps, track_res, plots=True, grid_res=0.5)
23
24# Do things with the observing dictionary results...
25
26# Close out
27smap_craft.unload()

API

class foam.spacecraft.spacecraft(sc_number=0)

Class defining spacecraft instrument and pointing characteristics for for ocean remote sensing on Earth. Each spacecraft object is numbered as a member of a constellation, and each spacecraft can be initialized with several microwave instruments.

Parameters

sc_number – Integer identifier of the spacecraft object within a constellation

The NAIF ID of a spacecraft in SPICE is -1500 - sc_number

write_tle_kernels(file=None, elems=None, tle_epoch=None, start_epoch=0.0, end_epoch=100.0, epoch_res=10)

Writing kernels for an orbiting spacecraft. Written kernels include spk, sclk, ck, fk. Separate CKs must be written for each radiometer

Parameters

  • file – File name of the TLE file used to initialized kernels. Must be specified if mode=’file’

  • elems – List of orbital elements (see spacecraft.get_manual_elems)

  • tle_epoch – Epoch for elements (see spacecraft.get_manual_elems)

  • start_epoch – Starting epoch of the spacecraft operation period in seconds past J2000

  • end_epoch – Ending epoch of the spacecraft operation period in seconds past J2000

  • epoch_res – Time resolution for kernel calculations in seconds

Spacecraft CK coordinate system is X -> toward planet, Y -> Orbital velocity vector

write_radiometer_ck(look_angle, look_axis, rpm, scan_axis, antenna_pattern=None)

Writes the camera kernel for a given radiometer. This can be called multiple times with different ck numbers to create several radiometers

Parameters

  • look_angle – Look angle in degrees

  • look_axis – Reference axis for look angle rotation Either ‘X’, ‘Y’, ‘Z’ in spacecraft frame or a vector A negative sign can also be added e.g. -X

  • rpm – Revolutions per minute of scan platform.

  • scan_axis – Scan rotation axis Either ‘X’, ‘Y’, ‘Z’ in spacecraft frame or a vector A negative sign can also be added e.g. -X

  • antenna_pattern – Text file describing radiometer antenna pattern This is a placeholder for future functionality.

Spacecraft CK coordinate system is X -> toward planet, Y -> Orbital velocity vector and radiometer CK is defined relative to the spacecraft system using the input arguments

write_stationary_kernels(sub_long, sub_lat, height)

Writes SPICE kernels for a stationary spacecraft with a single pointing

Parameters

  • sub_long – Sub-Observer longitude in degrees

  • sub_lat – Sub-Observer latitude in degrees

  • height – Height above sub-observer point in km

This routine is currently broken, and will raise an error if called.

make_track_grid(start_epoch, end_epoch, resolution)

Generates a sequence of sub-spacecraft latitutdes and longitudes

Parameters

  • start_epoch – Observation start epoch

  • end_epoch – Observation end epoch

  • resolution – Time resolution of tracks

Returns

A dictionary of longitudes, latitudes, and epochs

make_obs_grid(start_epoch, end_epoch, resolution, bounds=None)

Generates a sequence of latitudes, longitudes and angles of observations between the start and end epochs with a given time resolution for each radiometer instrument on the spacecraft

Parameters

  • start_epoch – Observation start epoch

  • end_epoch – Observation end epoch

  • resolution – Time resolution of tracks

  • bounds – Tuple of tuples ((lower_lat, upper_lat), (lower_lon, upper_lon)) Default is None

Returns

A dictionary of epochs, longitudes, latitudes, incidence elevations (theta), incidence azimuths (phi), right ascension and declination in the direction of specular reflection, and flags for if the sun and moon are in that direction

The shape of the arrays in each dictionary value (except epochs) is NxM where N is the number of radiometers on the spacecraft, and M is the length of the epochs value

make_antenna_grid(start_epoch, end_epoch, resolution, power_cutoff=0.5)

Similar to make_obs_grid, but each discrete observation contains an array of lat/lon/ra/dec values corresponding to rays sampling an antenna pattern

This routine is still under construction, and will raise an error when called

make_parallel_grid(start_epoch, end_epoch, resolution, bounds=None, ndiv=4, pool=None, nproc=4)

Parallel implementation of make_obs_grid, which computes the grid over subwindows using spacecraft copies

Parameters

  • start_epoch – Observation start epoch

  • end_epoch – Observation end epoch

  • resolution – Time resolution of tracks

  • bounds – Tuple of tuples ((lower_lat, upper_lat), (lower_lon, upper_lon)) Default is None

  • ndiv – Number of time blocks to feed to the pool (generally the same as ndiv)

  • pool – Process pool. If not assigned, this function creates one

  • nproc – Number of processes in the pool, overriden if pool is provided

Returns

A dictionary of epochs, longitudes, latitudes, incidence elevations (theta), incidence azimuths (phi), right ascension and declination in the direction of specular reflection, and flags for if the sun and moon are in that direction

The shape of the arrays in each dictionary value (except epochs) is NxM where N is the number of radiometers on the spacecraft, and M is the length of the epochs value

get_manual_elems(ndt2=0.0, ndd6=0.0, bstar=0.0, inclination=0.0, raan=0.0, eccentricity=0.0, argperigee=0.0, meananomaly=0.0, height=500000.0, tle_epoch=0.0)

A helper class that forms an element list from TLE inputs. Use this function also to reference the units for each parameter required for successful TLE kernel creation

Parameters

  • ndt2 – First derivative of mean motion in radians/minute^2

  • ndd6 – Second derivative of mean motion in radians/minute^3

  • bstar – Radiation pressure coefficient (unitless)

  • inclination – Inclination in radians

  • raan – Right Ascension of Ascending Node in radians

  • eccentricity – Eccentricity (unitless)

  • argperigee – Argument of Perigee in radians

  • meananomaly – Mean anomaly in radians

  • height – Height of semimajor axis above the surface of Earth in meters

  • tle_epoch – Epoch specified in the TLE set in seconds past J2000

Returns

A list of elements that can be used as an argument to spacecraft.write_tle_kernels

static read_tle(filename)

Reads TLE from file using the SPICE getelm function

Parameters

filename – TLE text file

Returns

  • epoch - SPICE formatted epoch

  • elements - SPICE formatted elements

write_tle_file(epoch=datetime.datetime(2000, 1, 1, 0, 0), inclination=0, raan=0, eccentricity=0, argperigee=0, meananomaly=0, height=0, revnumber=0)

Writes two line element strings from inputs All arguments should be floats except for epoch, which should be a datetime object Hardcoding the derivatives of mean motion and the radiation pressure drag to zero

Parameters

  • inclination – Inclination in radians

  • raan – Right Ascension of Ascending Node in radians

  • eccentricity – Eccentricity (unitless)

  • argperigee – Argument of Perigee in radians

  • meananomaly – Mean anomaly in radians

  • height – Height of semimajor axis above the surface of Earth in meters

  • revnumber – Number of revolutions around the Earth at the desired epoch

static specular_reflection(spoint, srfvec)

Calculates the specular reflection vector for a given spacecraft look direction

Parameters

  • spoint – Surface intercept point on target body

  • srfvec – Vector from observer to intercept point

Returns

RA, Dec in radians and unit vector in specular reflection direction

static check_moon_sun(epoch, point_vec)

Check if the moon and the sun intersect with a pointing vector. This can be used with the outputs of the specular_reflection function

foam.spacecraft.make_smap(start_epoch, end_epoch, epoch_res=1, sc_number=0)

Builds the SMAP spacecraft using the spacecraft module.

Spin platform rotation rate: 14.6 rpm

Antenna look angle (emission angle): 35.5 deg. (40 deg.)

Orbital altitude: 670 km

Integration time: 17.5 ms (resolution provided for level 1 products)

foam.spacecraft.make_aquarius(start_epoch, end_epoch, epoch_res=1, sc_number=0)

Builds the Aquarius spacecraft using the spacecraft module.

Horn angles: 25.8 deg., 33.8 deg., 40.3 deg.

Orbital altitude: 657 km

Integration time: 12s (resolution provided for level 1 products)

foam.spacecraft.track_viewer_2D(craft, start_epoch, end_epoch, resolution)

Plots spacecraft and radiometer look tracks on a 2D map

Parameters

  • craft – A spacecraft obect

  • start_epoch – Starting epoch in seconds

  • end_epoch – Ending epoch in seconds

  • resolution – Time resolution in seconds

foam.spacecraft.track_viewer_animated(craft, start_epoch, end_epoch, resolution, saveplots=True)

Animated plots spacecraft and radiometer look tracks on a 2D map overtime with a 3D plot of observing geometry

Parameters

  • craft – A spacecraft obect

  • start_epoch – Starting epoch in seconds

  • end_epoch – Ending epoch in seconds

  • resolution – Time resolution in seconds

foam.spacecraft.revisit_time(craft, start_epoch, end_epoch, epoch_res, grid_mode='linear', grid_res=0.25, grid_stop=1, plots=False, parallel=False, **kwargs)

Computes revisit counts for a spacecraft over a given time range

Parameters

  • craft – Spacecraft object

  • start_epoch – Starting epoch in seconds since J2000

  • end_epoch – Ending epoch in seconds since J2000

  • epoch_res – Time sample resolution in seconds

  • grid_mode –

    Options for grid mode are:

    • ’linear’ (default): Uniform lat/lon grid resolution set by grid_res

    • ’ease’: Scaled EASE grid with the finest grid resolution set by grid_res

    • ’cosine’: Uniform longitude spacing (grid_res) and a cosine-graded latitude spacing ranging from grid_res to grid_stop. Not exact!

  • grid_res – See above, in degrees

  • grid_stop – See above, in degrees. Only used for grid_mode=’cosine’

  • plots – If True, plot results as pcolormesh

  • parallel – If true, uses craft.make_parallel_grid (and associated kwargs), to generate observations in parallel

foam.spacecraft.angle_conversion(h, in_angle, in_angle_type='incidence', R=6371)

Utility to convert antenna look angle to Earth surface incidence angle or vice versa. Assumes either angle is < 90 deg

Parameters

  • h – Height above surface in km

  • in_angle – Input angle in degrees

  • in_angle_type – Either surface ‘incidence’ or antenna ‘look’

  • R – Radius of body in km (defaults to Earth, 6371)

foam.spacecraft.strings_to_epochs(*args)

Converts strings to epochs useable by spacecraft generator objects.

Example string format - ‘2020 MAY 24 9:00 UTC’

foam.spacecraft.merge_obs_dict(*args)

Merge any number of observing dictionaries into one
